ygData.subject: Re: Time Series with HyperNEAT

Time series prediction is a 1D problem and I am skeptical about the advanta=
ge of HyperNEAT over other methods like regular NEAT and other recurrent NN=
 based approaches. It seems that a lot of people got to know about HyperNEA=
T's ability to overcome a lot of challenges and then try to apply it to eve=
rything, without knowing it's internal workings, mainly the CPPN theory and=
 the way CPPNs generate patterns. Trying HyperNEAT on everything is good, t=
hough, it sheds light on what tasks the algorithm works and where it fails.=
 It would be good to know if HyperNEAT performs well in time series predict=
ion. Perhaps some kind of data preprocessing, which makes geometrical sense=
, should help. I personally have tried time series prediction with HyperNEA=
T and had no better results than regular NEAT, even worse. 

Peter

--- In =
neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> Peter, you coul=
d use any version of HyperNEAT currently available for your task, but the m=
ain question is whether the geometry (or regularities) of the time series c=
an somehow be made an advantage to HyperNEAT through the configuration of t=
he substrate.  It is not immediately clear why HyperNEAT in particular is a=
dvantageous for time series problems, though it is possible it can be lever=
aged in some way that is helpful.  
> 
> As an alternative, you could also =
try regular NEAT as well.  Also, if you search through the archives of this=
 group you will find a number of discussions on time series prediction.
> 
=
> ken
>
